caption: Brilliant, inspiring apartment. It was a beautiful day to visit and every room was breathtaking. I enjoyed the layout and the views on the rooftop. The balcony wasn't accessible, however there was no need as the views out from the dining, living and kitchen spaces was more than enough. A brilliant visit, that I hope to take my kids to explore and see one day.

The apartment in itself is beautiful and inspiring for anyone who is a Corbusier fan. However, my overall experience around the visit was a bit disappointing. When given a half an hour timeframe (which is quite tight already), one would hope to actually be able to utilize the full 30 minutes to explore the apartment without rushing through.  Firstly the staff managing the visit didn’t arrive or let us into the building until a couple of minutes after the set starting time at 13:30. Secondly, while I don’t mind walking up 7 flights of stairs at all, it did take some time - which I don’t think should be time included in the 30 minute timeframe itself considering time is already precious. Once upstairs it took another couple of minutes until they let us into the actual apartment, leaving around only 20 or so minutes for the actual visit. And with 5 minutes left, they told us the visit was over and that we had to leave as they had another group (the guided tour) starting at 14:00.  Overall - it’s worth a visit and I really enjoyed it, but it did feel rushed and was definitely shorter than the advertised 30 minutes. Hoping it was a one off rather than the standard.
So so.  Need to climb 7 stairs and sight is mediocre.  The official can be unresponsive.  Credit card reader did not work for me.  Visit Savoy instead.

Incredible to see and experience, lovely collection of items from Le Corbusier’s life. Went for a guided tour, which was excellent and explained the design choices and changes made during the course of Le Corbusiers life. Visited with a combined ticket with the nearby Villa La Roche  - would recommend .
I love this place and visit every time I am in Paris. FYI - I was here in May 2024, and the facade is being renovated and therefore covered. This however does not prevent you from going inside.
Very rude staff. We came from far and they told us to leave because there was too many people. They did not even let us in. We came to Paris specifically for this visit
Cute little visit. The apartment is on the penthouse level. The reservation system guarantees that it isn’t ever crowded, so there’s space to take in all the details.
The space is of course very interesting but poorly kept, for the price you'd expect a larger visit, some more info provided and better maintenance.
Great experience, very well presented, friendly staff.
Would be cool if the timetable on the website updated to the fact it is not open

The choice by Le Corbusier in terms of location for his flat are well done. The bedroom is very peculiar with high legs bed to see the panorama out of the window. Be prepared to 6 floor staircase (unless you don't care of the advice, don't disturb the neighbours). Pay attention to timing close to lunch break is useless to use the interphone to go in.

Arrived at 5.10pm on a Saturday . Was kept waiting until 5:25pm by the security guard and then someone from inside the apartment came out and told us they were closed - despite having already paid for a ticket and the website saying last entry was 5.30pm and closure was 6pm. Disappointing behaviour by the staff.
Nice to visit Overpriced
It's ok, but don't expect something really extremely outstanding. If you like le Corbusier you will definitely love the place) otherwise go somewhere else
Very interesting place, designed by le corb. He lived on the uppermost floors. When arriving take the lift or stairs to the top floors, and enjoy!!
Pretty inspiring for architecture students. For those who have visited and seen the bedroom and wondering about his bed, it is elevated in order for him to see the city from his window.
Yes! Small, out of the way (not counting soccer stadiums) but rewards extended contemplation.
We profited from the guided tour (in French) that was given at 15 o’clock. Would definitely recommend.
Incredible. Must see.
Such a surprising and interesting place to see, wonderful experience. I highly recommend visiting. Friendly staff.
Fascinating immersion into the world of Le Corbusier - a curious man who had the right ideas at the right time.
Amazing studio space. Love the huge integrated door with wardrobe.
A must see in Boulogne! Don't forget to book your tour in advance
A must visit for Le Corbu fans.
If you are a Corbusier lover,  you should have been here !!
Take into considaration: seven flores no elevator
Thrilling glimpse into the private life of a genius
Fascinating to learn about LeCorbusier!
You can see how he thought
Very nice service
Amazing place!
woooo
History
Interesting

A visit to Le Corbusier’s studio apartment is an important and unforgettable moment in the life of any architect. It's like a pilgrimage. We discover the history of the master, his place of life and work, the guided tour is very interesting intellectually speaking, the guides are very efficient, pleasant and educational and explain the history of the place very well.
I always remember with wonder LC's apartment-studio, installed on the two upper floors of the innovative Molitor building from the 1930s, which posed many challenges for the great architect.

There were website problems booking the guided tour so I wasn't able to book online but I showed up before the start time and was able to take part in this very interesting tour. I went on a Sunday afternoon and there weren't too many people, it was pleasant to wander around the spaces and for the guided tour, a small group is ideal.  The price is more than fair and the place is seriously worth the detour, the panoramic views from the apartment/workshop are magnificent, the NB photographs in the place are sublime, the guide and the visit were fascinating,..  In short, I had a great time. Curious to see the building present in Poissy.  The only two small problems were access: there is no indication / signage (luckily I had my phone) and you have to go up the 7 floors without an elevator because it is reserved for residents of the building but these two points were not disturbing for the pleasant time that I spent in this astonishing place.

The very inspiring Corbusier's former residence, located on the top seventh floor (there is an elevator, but requires taking the stairs) is worth a visit. It’s a great place to be inspired. It’s a great place to be. It’s architectural, jarring, and unique in style. It’s a great place to be and it’s a great place to be.
